articles.headline: Gig Workers Say High Gas Prices May Be a Breaking Point
articles.snippet: Some drivers say they find it hard to justify spending hours on the road for Uber or Lyft as fuel costs continue to tick upward.
articles.abstract: Some drivers say they find it hard to justify spending hours on the road for Uber or Lyft as fuel costs continue to tick upward.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Adam Potash started driving for Lyft six months ago to help make ends meet, he was happy with the pay. The business was far from lucrative, but he was making about $200 a day before paying for costs like gas and car maintenance.

articles.headline: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
articles.snippet: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.
articles.abstract: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A day after a Russian strike reduced to rubble a theater in southern Ukraine where hundreds of people had been huddling for shelter, rescuers wading through the debris — even as Russian shells kept falling — began pulling out survivors one by one.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney

articles.headline: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
articles.snippet: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
articles.abstract: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s government is “openly neo-Nazi” and “pro-Nazi,” controlled by “little Nazis,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says.

articles.headline: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
articles.snippet: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Biden declared to reporters on Wednesday, almost off the cuff, that President Vladimir V. Putin was a “war criminal,” he was speaking from the heart, his aides said, reacting to the wrenching images of civilians — including children — being dragged, dead or disfigured, from ruins of buildings shelled by Russian forces.

articles.headline: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
articles.snippet: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.
articles.abstract: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has shaken the global market for nickel just as the metal gains importance as an ingredient in electric car batteries, raising fears that high prices could slow the transition away from fossil fuels.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Gandel

articles.headline: China’s Information Dark Age Could Be Russia’s Future
articles.snippet: Russia and China have the tendency to learn the worst from each other: tyrants, famines, purges and, now, internet censorship.
articles.abstract: Russia and China have the tendency to learn the worst from each other: tyrants, famines, purges and, now, internet censorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russia blocked Facebook and limited Twitter this month, many Chinese internet users were surprised. Wait a moment, they said: The Russians could use Facebook and Twitter? Both social media platforms have been banned in China since 2009.

articles.headline: Where State Farm Sees ‘a Lot of Fraud,’ Black Customers See Discrimination
articles.snippet: The giant insurer is facing lawsuits from customers, agents and former employees accusing it of racial discrimination.
articles.abstract: The giant insurer is facing lawsuits from customers, agents and former employees accusing it of racial discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took years for Darryl Williams to build up the small real estate portfolio that became Connectors Realty, his business on the South Side of Chicago. In early 2017, when a pipe burst in his prized property — a building containing six apartments — Mr. Williams turned to his insurer, State Farm, to help repair the damage.

articles.headline: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
articles.snippet: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
articles.abstract: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The day after Russia invaded Ukraine, Pope Francis broke protocol and went directly to the Russian Embassy in the Holy See to appeal for peace. The next day he spoke to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, offering him spiritual support. As the war intensified, he raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” and the “barbarism of the killing of children.”

articles.headline: Colleges Can Avoid Shutting the Door on Financial Aid Knowledge
articles.snippet: We review Whitman College’s financial aid guarantee and Muhlenberg College’s refreshing explainer.
articles.abstract: We review Whitman College’s financial aid guarantee and Muhlenberg College’s refreshing explainer.
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, scores of applicants to Muhlenberg and Whitman Colleges received offers of admission. Perhaps they were a pleasant surprise for students who had sleepZoomed their way through junior year.

articles.headline: As Offices Open and Mask Mandates Drop, Some Anxieties Set In
articles.snippet: Using local guidelines, many companies are loosening Covid safety rules, leaving workers to navigate masking and social distancing on their own.
articles.abstract: Using local guidelines, many companies are loosening Covid safety rules, leaving workers to navigate masking and social distancing on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers are embracing a workplace atmosphere reminiscent of prepandemic times — elevators jammed, snack tables brimming, face coverings optional — even as a new subvariant of the Omicron coronavirus spurs concerns about health and safety. Across the country, office occupancy has hit a pandemic high, 40 percent, reached just once before in early December, at the same time that indoor mask mandates drop.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Lananh Nguyen
